newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan central banker cautiously bullish on economy.
newsitem.headline: Japan central banker cautiously bullish on economy.

text.p: Japan's central bank governor struck a cautiously bullish stance on the nation's economy on Monday but signalled that interest rates will be kept low so as to maintain the momentum of recovery.
His remarks boosted the yen against the dollar.

Governor Yasuo Matsushita told a news conference that Japanese companies were still cautious about the future as they were continuing to adjust their business structures to get out of a prolonged slump.
"The economy is continuing to recover gradually. The strength of the economic recovery appears to be becoming more solid," he said on a trip to western Japan.
Japan's industrial output was rising more rapidly, he said.

Leading the increasing production was brisk sales of cars in Japan. The Japan Automobile Dealers' Association said on Monday that domestic vehicle sales in November rose 14 percent from a year earlier to 507,548 units.
Financial markets took Matsushita's remarks as indicating that Japan's economy may be stronger than expected, which could lead to a credit-tightening some time in the future.
The comments prompted selling of the dollar against the yen, pushing down the U.S. currency. The dollar was hovering around 113.80 yen in late Tokyo trading on Monday.
Matsushita was not entirely upbeat, however.
"We can well expect a favourable economic cycle of production creating income and then consumption to strengthen further. However, we still need to make sure this is on track," he said.

Asked about the Bank of Japan's monetary policy, Matsushita said: "We will put emphasis on ensuring a basis for economic recovery while keeping close watch on economic conditions." This was taken as a signal that no change in interest rate policy is imminent.
The central bank has kept its official discount rate, which it charges on lending to commercial banks, at a historic low of 0.5 percent since September last year.
The BOJ declared in February that the nation's economy had finally come out of the slump that followed the collapse in the early 1990s of the "bubble" economy of inflated asset prices.
But economic indicators have shown the pace of recovery has not been picking up, and many economists suspected that the economy actually came to a halt in the summer.
Pressures from structural adjustments and an expected fall in public works spending are still keeping Japanese companies cautious about their future prospects, he added.

Many economists predict the economic recovery will slow in the coming months, with a fall in public works spending, and especially after a planned rise in the consumption tax next April to five percent from the current three percent.

Matsushita said the central bank's easy money policy was intended to prevent a deflationary spiral, to strengthen corporate confidence and to put the economy back on a self-sustainable recovery track.
The first two aims had "just about been achieved", he said.
